race.name: Atlas Mountain Race
race.tagline: Moroccan Atlas Mountains ultra-endurance gravel race.

terrain.surface: Gravel roads and tracks through Atlas Mountains. Extreme elevation with mountain and desert scenery. Self-supported ultra-endurance format.

gravel_god_rating.score_note: Ultra-endurance adventure race. Extreme Atlas Mountains terrain with very difficult access, high costs, and small field.

biased_opinion.summary: Atlas Mountain Race is an ultra-endurance self-supported race through Morocco—750 miles with 80,000 feet of climbing. The Atlas Mountains are stunning and the adventure is extreme, but the very difficult access, extreme conditions, high costs, and self-supported format keep it in Tier 3.
biased_opinion.bottom_line: An extreme Atlas Mountains ultra-endurance adventure. Worth it for elite ultra-endurance riders with big budgets. Not practical for most riders.

final_verdict.one_liner: Moroccan Atlas Mountains ultra-endurance gravel race.
final_verdict.should_you_race: If you're an elite ultra-endurance rider with a big budget—maybe. For most riders—there are better options.
final_verdict.alternatives: For similar ultra-endurance: Transcontinental Race. For better value: regional gravel races.

logistics.food: Self-supported. Carry all nutrition and resupply in villages.

history.origin_story: Ultra-endurance self-supported race through Atlas Mountains.

course_description.signature_challenge: 750 miles and 80,000 feet through Atlas Mountains.

non_negotiables.why: 750 miles requires months of ultra-endurance preparation.

marketplace_variables.race_hook: Moroccan Atlas Mountains ultra-endurance gravel race.

logistics.explanation: Michael Drummond describes "1145km, One thousand, one hundred and forty five kilometres of mystery. The only true 'knowledge' gleaned from select vistas." No published entry fees, airport details, or packet pickup information for Morocco. Race provides GPX tracking and three staffed checkpoints across 750 miles—everything else is self-supported navigation through remote Atlas passes.

length.explanation: Rory Stuart finished in "6 days 4 hours 45 minutes but later reflected: I wholeheartedly think I did pretty darn well. Sure, I could've slept less." At 750 miles, riders average less than 10mph including stops. Justinas Leveika warns "Don't get fooled by 'just' 160 km to the next CP. The average speed in this race is very low." Among the longest in gravel, comparable to Badlands.

technicality.explanation: Michael Drummond describes the Telouet Pass descent: "Rocks, boulders and well, more boulders strewn along a convoluted and rarely trodden route that winds down the back of this peak enveloped in thick darkness." Kevin Benkenstein notes "hours spent riding through dry river beds which consist of anything from sand and small stones to baby-head rocks." More technical than most — comparable to Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

elevation.explanation: The 2026 route includes Tizi N'Aït Imi—the highest pass at 2,910m—replacing the iconic Telouet Pass. 80,000 feet of climbing over 750 miles means constant elevation gain through Atlas Mountain crossings. James Hayden experienced "a 10-kilometre climb at 10 percent in 35-degree heat" as his welcome back to the Atlas. Among the hilliest in gravel, comparable to Badlands.

climate.explanation: Jochen Böhringer faced "stiff wind, then heavy rain adds and finally the temperatures drop to 5°C while thunderbolts lighten the dark" followed by flooding that stopped the race. Justinas Leveika experienced "temperatures from -7 to + 25°c" in a single edition. James Hayden notes February brings "0 Celsius at night" despite 30°C daytime temperatures. More weather exposure than Belgian Waffle Ride San Diego.

altitude.explanation: The new route crosses Tizi N'Aït Imi at 2,910m, the highest pass ever included in AMR. Michael Drummond's Telouet Pass experience at 2,600m involved sustained hike-a-bike: "feet again make connection with terra firma and the bike is used as a cumbersome hiking partner." Multiple high passes require altitude acclimatization while carrying full bikepacking loads. Higher altitude racing, comparable to SBT GRVL.

adventure.explanation: The route explores new M'Goun gorges where "riders will follow a mule trail through the river itself" according to race organizers. Valerio Stuart describes terrain that "looked at times like Utah and at times like Spain" approaching the Cathedral d'Imsfrane rock formation. Michael Drummond encountered sand sections he calls "billions of microscopic permutations of glass with an appetite for tyre and energy."

prestige.explanation: Six years running as part of The Mountain Races series alongside Silk Road and Hellenic Mountain races. Jochen Böhringer found himself "fighting for 3rd place with Philippe Vullioud after Justinas Leveika (1st) and Marin de Saint-Exupéry (2nd)." The February timing attracts serious bikepacking talent, but the field remains smaller than marquee gravel events.

race_quality.explanation: Flooding stopped the 2022 race when "heavy rain dramatically increased the water level of a close-by river to a level that we cannot cross it with our bikes anymore," forcing riders to wait at a gas station. Three checkpoints across 750 miles provides minimal race infrastructure. No published entry fees or detailed race manual suggests organizational gaps.

experience.explanation: Shona and Rich note "The locals are really friendly and often just want a quick chat to know what you're up to and if you like their country. They're normally on a donkey going faster than you are." The Old Colonial Road impressed Jochen Böhringer as "an incredible marvel of engineering" balanced on mountainsides. Pure Atlas Mountain wilderness from Beni-Mellal to the Atlantic.

community.explanation: It attracts the bikepacking crowd more than racers, which creates a weird vibe when some people are touring and others are actually competing. The race might be popular, but it's not building the kind of vocal tribe that defines great gravel events.

field_depth.explanation: When the top three are separated by 40 minutes after 1350km, you're not looking at deep competitive talent. The mix of racing and touring mentalities means half the field is there for the Instagram shots, not the podium. No notable past winners or pro participation mentioned anywhere tells you everything about the competitive level. Less competitive depth than Almanzo 100. As Ozogan puts it: "Scratching has an unusually high rate for the Atlas Mountain Race. Over 100 people out of 270 didn't finish."

value.explanation: Riders get exclusive access to new M'Goun gorge sections and mule trails impossible to replicate privately. Mel Webb's packing challenges—"Standing at 5'2, she's no stranger to the game of tetris that is packing a small bike"—highlight the specialized gear investment required. The adventure justifies costs for those who finish, but international travel and self-sufficiency gear add up quickly.

expenses.explanation: Registration runs €200-300. Morocco isn't cheap to reach, and when you factor in international flights, gear for desert crossings, GPS tracker rental, and eight days of complete self-sufficiency, you're looking at serious money. The race won't even publish entry fees, which usually means they're embarrassed by the number. Add in the risk of expensive gear failure in remote Atlas passes and this becomes a rich person's adventure. More expensive than UCI Gravel Suisse.

primary.name: Schwalbe G-One Bite
primary.why: Technical terrain dominator. Aggressive grip when the course gets rowdy.

primary.name: Maxxis Reaver
primary.why: Technical all-rounder. EXO+ casing shrugs off rocks and roots.

primary.name: Pirelli Cinturato Gravel S
primary.why: Soft-terrain specialist. Open knob pattern sheds mud and grips wet rock.

videos.title: Into the Rift : The Story of the PEdALED Atlas Mountain Race
videos.description:
To simply finish the Atlas Mountain Race means navigating 1,200 kilometres of the most rugged and remote roads in Morocco. To win requires riding almost non-stop, night and day, for days on end. It is a combination of strength and sleep deprivation that only a few riders in the world can manage. Alone, unsupported and loaded down with supplies, each competitor must constantly battle mechanicals, heat exhaustion and saddle sores to get to the finish. There is no prize, no money, simply the satisfaction that comes from pushing oneself to the limit while exploring the forgotten corners of a beautiful country.

With support from PEdALED, Canyon, Fizik and the race crew led by organiser and route creator Nelson Trees, filmmaker Brady Lawrence followed the race documenting everything from a brutal 80 kilometre walk through the high desert with a broken bike, to one racer’s simple joy at realising they’ll soon eat their first warm meal in days. Featuring the sport’s biggest names and first-time, ultra-distance racers alike, the film gets up close to the kind of people crazy enough to take on this epic challenge. Capturing the human drama set against an otherworldly landscape, Into the Rift is an in-depth look at a true cycling adventure.

videos.title: Rigs of the 2024 Atlas Mountain Race: An Analysis of Stats, Tire Sizes, Bags and More
videos.description:
The 2024 Atlas Mountain Race (AMR) kicks off today, and over 200 racers will set out to tackle the race's fourth edition across Morocco. This year, racers will travel 800 miles (1,300 kilometers) from Marrakesh to Essaouira. The AMR has become one of the world's most popular self-supported ultra-endurance races, as evidenced by the more than 100 race rig submissions we received. In our latest video, Neil unpacks the rigs and shares some interesting findings.

This video was supported by Tailfin, learn more about Tailfin here: https://www.tailfin.cc?utm_source=bikepacking.com&utm_medium=paid_video&utm_campaign=bikepacking_neil

Outline
Intro: 0:00
Race Details: 0:34
Bikes and Bars: 1:47
Tires: 3:48
Drivetrains: 4:57
Bikepacking Gear: 7:21
Demographics: 8:47
Other Findings: 9:47

Mentioned Links:
ATLAS MOUNTAIN RACE RIGS OF PT 1 - https://bikepacking.com/bikes/2024-atlas-mountain-race-rigs-part-1/
ATLAS MOUNTAIN RACE RIGS OF PT 2 - https://bikepacking.com/bikes/2024-atlas-mountain-race-rigs-part-2/
2023 TOUR DIVIDE RIGS BREAKDOWN STATS ANALYSIS - https://bikepacking.com/bikes/2023-rigs-of-the-tour-divide-breakdown/

videos.title: ATLAS MOUNTAIN RACE: The story of my first Ultra-Distance Bikepacking Race
videos.description:
1173 kilometres. Over 20,000 meters of climbing. Non-stop and self-supported. Five days of off-road ultra bikepacking through the Moroccan desert. This is my story of the Atlas Mountain Race 2022.

See the rides on Strava: https://www.strava.com/athletes/tristancardew
Follow me on Instagram: https://www.instagram.com/tristantakephoto/
View my photography: http://www.tristantakephoto.com
Learn more about AMR: https://www.atlasmountainrace.cc

Supported by BMC, ATTAQUER, and WINFORCE

Special thanks to Ricard Calmet (@erreka) for the footage of me at the finish.

Music from Epidemic Sound: (free trial affiliate link): https://www.epidemicsound.com/referral/slnb1q

Atlas Mountain Race was created by ultra cyclist Nelson Trees. The same event organiser responsible for the Silk Road Mountain Race. Both ultracycling races are considered among the toughest on earth, attracting international interest, acclaim, and participation by riders like Sofiane Sehili, James Hayden, Team Amani, Josh Ibett, Marin de St Exupery and more.

videos.title: My HARDEST Challenge Yet! Bikepacking 800 Miles across Morocco ( Solo & Unsupported )

Thank you so much for watching! Take care & Keep Smiling :)

videos.curation_reason: Recent 2025 first-person race experience with strong viewership and personal journey narrative.

videos.title: RACING THE ATLAS MOUNTAIN RACE
videos.description:
L'Atlas Mountain Race è una gara di 1300Km attraverso le montagne dell'Atlante e Anti Atlante in Marocco. Parte a Marrakech e arriva ad Essaouira, Seguendo Piste sabbiose, mulattiere e Vecchie strade coloniali abbandonate in aree remote e poco visitate.

La gara è senza supporto e ogni partecipante deve portarsi il necessario per essere autosufficienti. 
Questo è il Video della mia esperienza, ho completato il percorso in 4 giorni, 18 ore , 24 minuti, posizionandomi quattordicesimo assoluto.


0:00 Intro
1:05 First night
2:22 Day 1
8:01 Day 2
11:34 Day 3
14:26 Day 4
15:57 Day 5

quotes.text: It's 4:30 in the morning and I'm currently hiking my bike up an unridable trail somewhere outside of Agadir in Morocco. I've been living on about 2 and a half, 3 hours sleep a night for the last four nights, been wearing the same kit for the last 5 days, I smell terrible.

One of the toughest days I've ever had on a bike, just that climb we knew it was gonna be hike-a-bike coming down but there was just like this stream of ants going up the far side. You get to the top it's cold, just as the sun was setting, and then just big rocks, bike going not where you wanted it to, couldn't see where you were going.
So it took me all night to get over Tizi n'Tichka pass which is over 2,000 meters and it was a savage, savage pass.
